 Think of the universe as a loaf of raisin bread rising in an oven. The universe is expanding in the same way as the rising loaf. Now pick any raisin, and imagine it's our own Milky Way galaxy. No matter how you look at it, as the bread rises, all the other raisins are moving away from our raisin. The farther away another raisin is from our raisin, the faster it is moving away. In the same way, all the other galaxies are moving away from ours as the universe expands. And because the universe is uniformly expanding, the farther a galaxy is from Earth, the faster it is receding from us."

 
 Terral continues << Please allow me to ask a few questions, and use this opportunity to forward a thought: 
 
 Suppose we choose a spot beyond the physical universe and observe these things from the outside. Whether we use your balloon example, or the rising loaf of raisin bread illustration, would we still see red shift values for all the galaxies? 
 
 Or, would we only see longer wavelengths values from those galaxies on the far side of the universe, and those on either side? 
 
 After all, the galaxies on the near side of the expanding universe should be coming closer to us. And, those galaxies very near us should be approaching at the greatest speeds. In this case, the galaxies near the middle of the expanding universe would have very low red shift values (the very center being zero), with those on the left and right outside edges having higher values. But still, those galaxies in our direct line of vision (straight across the center of the universe) would show extremely high blue shift values (near us), and the highest red shift values farther away along our perspective line. So the blue shift values would be the highest for the galaxy cluster nearest to us, and the very highest red shift value would come from that cluster farthest away. 
 
 If my thinking on this is correct, then there should be a way to find the center of your expanding balloon by mapping the variations in red shift values from any inside point of perspective. Let us try to visualize this by drawing a circle on a piece of paper. Then divide the circle into quadrants, by drawing an X inside; like dividing a pie into four equal parts. Number the quadrants 1, 2, 3 (opposite 1), and 4. Put our Milky Way Galaxy in the first quadrant. As you said, since our universe is expanding, then all of the galaxies have positive red shift values. But, the 'average' red shift value for all galaxy chains in quadrants 2 and 4 should be identical (assuming our perspective line is in the very center of quad 1, and the rate of expansion is constant). By contrast, the red shift values for the galaxy chains that share space in our quadrant 1 should be much lower, than those in quadrant 3. 
 
 If we find that magical 'average' red shift value for all the galaxy chains in quads 2 and 4 (to our left and right sides), and subtract that number from the value from each of our four quad values, then we should see a definite pattern. If the center of the X inside our pie represents the center of your expanding balloon, then the red shift value for quads 2 and 4 would be zero, because x - x = 0. However, the value for those chains in quad 1 would now be negative. The average red shift number for quad 3 galaxies should now be the only positive values on our map with lesser values near us, and higher values as for those farther away. Also, those galaxies between us and the center of the universe should display the lowest red shift values of all.
 
 By drawing perspective lines in every direction, and mapping the corresponding red shift values from the created quadrants, we should see a spectrum of varying positive values for quad 3, IF and only, if your balloon illustration accurately depicts our universe. In that case, the three dimensional mapping of our varying quad 3 values should act as a divining rod that would lead us to the center of the universe. Our perspective lines that actually point away from the center would present us with positive values for quad 3, but the decimal number following the 1 would always be lower than the lines drawn near the center of the universe. The perspective line that points directly away from the center of the universe should give us the lowest average red shift value for distant galaxies. 
 
 Suppose we find that the average quad 3 values are identical for every possible direction? One possibility is that God Almighty chose a point in the center of the universe to perform His work of redemption. That being said, today I am inclined to stand with you and assume that we are not in the middle of anything. However, if the average quad 3 red shift number actually turns out to be a constant value for every given point in the universe, then I believe the Big Bang (balloon/raisin bread) theory goes right out the window. That would 'appear' [my disclaimer : 0 ) ] to indicate that our universe is expanding from the center of every given point. If that turned out to the case, then I feel it would be time for each and every one of us to accept the fact that there is no possibility that creation came into being through random means. 
 
 Either way, I believe the day shall come when men come to realize that creation has a Creator. Scripture says, "For since the creation of the world His invisible attributes, His eternal power and divine nature, have been clearly seen, being understood through what has been made, so that they are without excuse." Rom. 1:20. He says, "It is I who made the earth, and created man upon it. I stretched out the heavens with My hands And I ordained all their hosts." Isa. 45:12. And, "For My hand made all these things, Thus all these things came into being," declares the LORD." Isa. 66:2. 
 
 Thank you again for pointing out the weakness of my original view. Please look my theory over and show where I appear to be off. Thanks again,
 
 In Christ,
 
 Terral

I've always enjoyed cosmology, but I'm not a pro. Some of this will be things I've learned, and some will be guesses. I'll try to keep it clear which is which.
 
 First off, just the idea of trying to look at the universe from the outside makes my brain hurt. Certainly you wouldn't be able to see anything in our universe from the outside, because light from anything in our universe has to travel through space (not outer space space, but space-time space) and since space as we know it ends at the edge of the universe (if there is such a thing) then light certainly couldn't "get out." Or, to look at it another way, the edge of the universe is expanding outward at the speed of light, so light from the inside of the universe could never catch up in order to get out and be seen. I suppose that whatever passes for light could travel through whatever passes for space outside our universe, bounce off the advancing edge of our universe, and be observed, but I really can't wrap my brain around that too well.
 
 So, let's stay inside the universe. Your idea with the quadrants is a good one, but it has one flaw. Quadrants 2 and 4 will always have the same average red shift, which will be greater than 1's and less than 3's, regardless of whether the X is at the center of the universe or not. The red shift value is dependent solely on how far away something is, so if we're in the middle of quad 1, quad 3 will always have a higher red shift than quads 2 and 4, regarless of how we orient the map.
 
 However, you did give me an idea. Here comes the guesses. ;) 
 Take a well nigh infinitely powerful telescope. So powerful that we could see the radiation generated at the edge of the universe as it advances away from us. By measuring the red shift on that it may, in theory, be possible to find out how far away the edge is in that direction. Repeat in every direction until you have the shape of the universe and our relative position in it. This all assumes, of course, that concepts like "shape of the universe" and "edge of the universe" have any useful meaning, which I'm not entirely sure of.
